content: Nice challenge.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is an interesting problem :-)
Please give the "number of integers in numbers" in inputs & in stub.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Finally a unique competitive clash I can approve without hesitation.

Goal is easily understandable, and first example alone is a great description therefore a perfect fit for Reverse mode.

Test cases and validators are solid.

Looks good to go, thanks for the contribution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good to me.

All of the interval extents are multiples of 10. Vary that a little. An extent of "1" should be one of the cases.

There are no cases where a duplicate number appears, and no instructions for handling such duplicates.

There should be a test case where all numbers fit into a single interval.

The Constraints section should mention that there is guaranteed to be at least one number in the list.

The only time that the highest interval contains only a number right on the boundary is a validator (Validator 1, where '50' appears in the last interval). Since boundary conditions are notoriously tricky, there should be a test case with that situation, e.g. in Test 2 changed the "932" to "900"

I don't really like that there is a parsing to do on the input. The exercise is interesting enough without it. There is a reason why Codingame gives the parsing part, it's for beginners to struggle a little less on this part and focus on the problem itself and also give less of an advantage to high-level languages.
You could have the input as follow and change the stub generator accordingly :
first line : the interval
second line : n
third line : n space separated integers

Also just to make it a little clearer the intervals could be :
10-19 : 1 (12)
20-29 : 0
30-39 : 2 (30, 35)
40-49 : 0
50-59 : 0
60-69 : 1 (63)

The sentence "If a number x is divisible by d, it has to be allocated to the interval whose lower limit is x." is not in the right section and is not really necessary anyway.

For the output don't give too much detail on the  formatting, you can put something like:
One line for each interval from the first non-empty interval to the last non-empty interval.
For each line, write the limits of the interval, the count and sorted list of integers in the interval, as in the example below.

Each pair of test case and validator should be similar but remain different. Please revise the cases.

Stub generator: Please add a write statement.

Thanks.
OK, I've modified the problematic parts.

Thank you very much for your very useful comment. Greatly appreciated ! Yes, I was thinking about adding an integer in the input section to indicate the extent of the intervals. I didn't know about the advantage given to high-level languages.
Thank you for the suggestions.
Thank you for your careful review.
Thank you very much!

Your example input will be like this:
10
4
28 60 30 35
Thank you.
Done. It may be clearer now, what do you think?

Yes, it is clearer also, but mainly it's for making it less language dependent. Now, as we have already the n variable, we can use it in the stub also, so that different languages will have more or less equalized start.
That being said, please also replace this line in the stub:
read numbers:string(1000)
with the following line:
loopline n x:int
Done. Thanks for your review.

I like the new test cases.

The Constraints section is intended for giving the coder information about the range of inputs and outputs they might have to consider. (Python users can be lazy about that, but for other languages the coder may have to make a decision about the data type to create). So it should contain things like the minimum and maximum size of the interval and length of the input string, and that all numbers are positive integers. But it should not have the other two lines - I don't think you need the "Both limits of all intervals..." line at all, and the "The low limit of an interval is inclusive..." line belongs in the Goal or Output section.

Thank you for the explanation. The sentence "Both limits of all intervals are multiples of extent" is intended to explain how to build intervals (do not start from the lowest value in "numbers" for example).
